STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 13, 2022
Jennifer Vasilovski
Family and Community Services-Livingston
Suite 116
3075 E. Grand River Ave.
Howell, MI 48843
RE: License #: CB470382419
Family and Community Services-Livingston
Suite 116
3075 E. Grand River Ave.
Howell, MI 48843
Dear Ms. Vasilovski:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 5/5/2022.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Settlement Agreement (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is required.
It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved. For any repeat
violations please identify why the prior CAP did not correct the issue and
what steps will be taken to ensure ongoing compliance.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(2) The borrowing agency is responsible for securing the items
identified in subrules (1) (d) of this rule annually for the duration
of the child's placement.
One of three borrowed home files did not have agency endorsement for a renewal
evaluation completed on 11/22/21. The only endorsement on file was for the initial
review when the borrowed bed began on 1/22/21.
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time.
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child
and the foster parent in the foster parent's home at least once
every month.
One of eight foster care files reviewed was missing a monthly face to face contact
between the caseworker and child for February 2022.
R 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written
adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family signing an
adoption application and prior to approving a family for adoption.
Three of six adoptive evaluations were not completed within the required timeframe.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please
note that there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not
be included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
(Page 5) FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined… Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
4

(Page 16) Following the FTM, the caseworker is responsible for
the following:  Completing the DHS-1105, Family Team
Meeting Report.  Providing the DHS-1105, Family Team
Meeting Report, to all participants (in person and by phone),
legal parents, and casework supervisor. These documents must
also be uploaded into MISACWIS.
(Page 5) Two of eight foster care files did not have FTMs completed 30 days prior to
completing an updated service plan.
(Page 16) Four of eight foster care files did not have an 1105 completed to
document an FTM as required. Nor was an 1105 provided to FTM participants.
FOM 722-08D Treatment plan
Page 10
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
Four of eight foster care files held late or missing PATP signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cited as CI 17-099)
7/16/21 INTERIM, CAP approved 7/16/20.
FOM 722-08 Case service plans- overview, types, and timeframes
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
Two of eight foster care files each held one service plan that was not approved
within the required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cited as FOM 722-09)
7/16/20 INTERIM, CAP approved 7/16/20
FOM 801-03 Medical passport
Page 2-3
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties is
documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and dated
signature page into the Health Profile section.
Two of eight foster care files did not have quarterly updated medical passports
completed or provided to case participants as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cited as FOM 801)
5/5/21 RENEWAL, CAP approved 5/11/21
5

7/16/20 INTERIM, CAP approved 7/16/20
FOM 722-08E Foster care/juvenile justice action summary
Page 6
Within three business days of foster care or juvenile justice
program or case closure, the caseworker must document...
One of eight closed foster care cases did not have a closing summary completed
within the required timeframe.
FOM 722-06H Case contacts
Page 5
The primary caseworker must have face-to-face contact with
each child as indicated below...
The first face-to-face contact must take place within five
business days of the date of removal or placement change.
One of eight foster care cases did not make face to face contact within five days of
the child entering care.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Some licensing renewal letters indicated the family must complete an
application but did not indicate the application was provided. There must be
documentation in the file to show the date the application was provided in
order to determine the rule requirement was met.
 Case records, including USPs and PATPs, must clearly indicate when a
parent is non-participating.
 Borrowed Bed case files had a coversheet to document when items were
received, including endorsement of the reports received at the beginning of
the agreement. However, the agency should update the form to document
endorsement of subsequent reports received for the duration of the borrowed
bed agreement.
 DHHS-69’s must be completed within 3 days of case closure. However, if the
written closing court order is not immediately received, it is acceptable for the
agency to complete the DHHS-69 within 3 days of receiving the written court
order.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
6

 Rule 327(6c) requires the agency to provide a copy of a special evaluation
report to the caseworker for any children in the foster home. Although not
specified in the rule, the agency was advised it would be best practice to
provide this report to the worker for any children that were in the home at the
beginning of the evaluation but moved before it was completed. Especially if
the findings impact the ongoing care of the child.
 During the review it was observed some foster parents first aid/CPR was near
expiration, but an annual/renewal evaluation would not occur for several
months later. The agency was advised first aid/CPR dates should be tracked
outside of annual/renewal reviews, to ensure they do not expire before the
next annual evaluation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The CAP, approved 5/22/21, was submitted as a result of the 5/5/21 renewal
evaluation. During this review only one repeat violation regarding Medical Passports
was found. The agency has successfully implemented the CAP and shown
improvement in several areas. While there are nine violations cited in this review, the
occurrence of each violation was small.
Chief Administrator Assessment(CAA)
The CAA was reviewed and discussed during the entrance meeting on 4/18/22. The
Chief Adminstrator (CA) identified prior violations regarding foster parent training,
special evaluations, service plans, medical exams, medical passports, and
supervisory approval of reports. The CA indicated the pandemic and staffing had an
effect on some areas of compliance. The CA reported fully implementing the CAP
and continuing to review and assess progress with staff and leadership over the past
year. It was noted in the CAA that despite the licensing violations most metrics show
compliance of 80-95%.
Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two agency staff. Both staff had been with the
agency approximately three years, one in licensing and one in foster care. Both
stated they felt supported by management and felt it was a wonderful place to work.
Staff reported no concerns about the agency.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
7

Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
_ ______________May 12, 2022______________________
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
May 12, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
8
